message: Coffee ngo and colored pencil pursuits and growing up upstate all sound interesting - I’d love to hear more, and prefer in person conversations to tinder texting. Sounds like you’re a busy guy, but hit me up if you’re in the city and care to meet up (I’m also dangerously close to the Lafayette blick). Cell is 541-480-8905.
November trip was my first time in EA. We did Nairobi/Mt Kenya and then a week or so in Ethiopia (Addis + up by mekele). Had such a good time, itching to go back.

Not surprised you enjoyed the west coast; California’s pretty easy to fall in love with.  As far as intl moves go, I’m most attracted to medium/large cities with great food, solid infrastructure/public transit/airport, cool people, and access to outdoor pursuits. Mexico City, Geneva, Tokyo, Barcelona, and London are a few contenders, but open to recommendations!
Oh nice.  I saw today that buffalo made the times’ 2018 52 places list. My visit was quick and work related, but sounds like the town’s worth a real visit.

The best part about Buffalo that tourists never see? That’s such a difficult question. Perhaps Ellicottville if you like to ski, or our surprisingly diverse and excellent food scene, or Shakespeare in the park in summers, or … can I think more about this question and get back to you? What do you think the best part about buffalo is?

And Mt Kenya! I should have known from the sign. I’ve heard that Mt. Kenya is a nicer hike than Kili. Was November your first trip to east africa? I spend ~ 10% of my time with an NGO in the coffee sector that’s brings me to east africa every few months. I would like to take some time off next time I  go and either hike Kili, Mt. Kenya, or the Mt. Stanley in Rwenzori Mountains. I’m not sure when I’ll find the time, on my last trip in November I left New York to Hawassa Ethiopia on a thursday and was back at work on Monday. It’s difficult for me to disconnect from my job for more than a couple days.

My apartment in New York is 4 blocks from the Lafayette street Blick. I walk by it every day I go to my the office and have far too many art supplies. I was not familiar with CJ Hendry’s work until you mentioned her.  Her technique is amazing. Thank you for telling me about her.

I am from Buffalo and my parents still live here. I started a PhD on the west coast fell in love with California. I dropped out to start a company and there were a few years that I lived between Palo Alto and New York. I finally committed to being in new york city ‘full time’ last year and I miss the west coast so much. Especially lake Tahoe. I still work remotely about 50% of the time and spend most of it in Buffalo. I would like to live internationally as well. I don’t feel like I’m ready to settle down yet. Where would you like to try living?
You’re from buffalo? What’s the best part about buffalo that tourists never see?
I haven’t done Kili, but did Mount Kenya with friends in November, which was so, so great.

Came out east for college,  moved to NYC after school, and have been here since (though visited buffalo ~6 years ago). Oregon is beautiful. The best. I’m not finished with NY yet, and would like to live internationally at some point soon, but I imagine I’ll return to the PNW before too long.

Mm, sounds like a joyful — and carefully considered — pack. I am at best a JV colored pencil user myself, and probably more of a blender, but I’ve recently been taken with cj hendry’s brilliantly burnished complimentary colors. Winter seems like the right season to hit up blick and experiment with new tools and techniques.
What brought you from Oregon to Buffalo? Oregon is so beautiful. I could see myself moving to the PNW at some point. And what was climbing Kilimanjaro like? Did you take the coca-cola route?

Hey Campbell, it depends. Are you looking for wax based or oil based? How soft / hard do you like your pencils to be? Do you do much blending or burnishing? My favorite oils are faber-castell polychromos. If you don’t mind splurging I recommend a Holbein artist pack. If you don’t mind wax, on the budget side it’s hard to go wrong with prismacolor premier soft cores. Assuming the faber-castell polychromos, I would pick 110 (phthalo blue), 126 (permanent carmine), 105 (light cadmium yellow), 166 (grass green), and 160 (manganese violet). I apologize for taking over two months to answer your question. I had to think a lot about it.
You’re designing a 5-pack of colored pencils and you’re optimizing for joy. Which colors are in your pack?
